[[Mentioned in Despatches]] |laterwork= Aerospace consultant }} [[Air Commodore]] '''Gordon Henry Steege''', [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]], [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|DFC]] (31 October 1917 – 1 September 2013) was a senior officer in the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF). He became a [[flying ace|fighter ace]] in World War II, credited with eight aerial victories. Joining the RAAF in July 1937, Steege first saw action with [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|No. 3 Squadron]] in the [[Mediterranean and Middle East Theatre|Middle East]], where he was awarded the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] after shooting down three German aircraft in a single [[sortie]]. He rose to command [[No. 450 Squadron RAAF|No. 450 Squadron]] in the [[Desert Air Force]], before being posted to the [[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific]], where he led [[No. 73 Wing RAAF|Nos. 73]] and [[No. 81 Wing RAAF|81 Wings]]. He earned the [[Distinguished Service Order]] for his "outstanding leadership", and finished the war a temporary [[group captain]]. Resigning his commission following the end of World War II, Steege rejoined the RAAF during the [[Korean War]], and briefly took command of [[No. 77 Squadron RAAF|No. 77 Squadron]] late in 1951. Returning to Australia, he held senior administrative and training posts before taking charge of [[Fairbairn, Canberra|RAAF Base Canberra]] in 1957. In the 1960s he was appointed to various planning positions, followed by command of [[RAAF Base Amberley]], Queensland, and later [[RMAF Butterworth|RAAF Base Butterworth]], Malaysia. Having been raised to air commodore, his final appointment before retiring in 1972 was on the staff of Headquarters Operational Command (now [[RAAF Air Command|Air Command]]) at [[RAAF Base Glenbrook]], New South Wales. He subsequently became an aeronautical consultant, and died in Sydney in 2013, aged 95. ==Early career== The son of William and Ida Steege, Gordon Henry Steege was born in the Sydney suburb of [[Chatswood, New South Wales|Chatswood]] on 31 October 1917, and educated at [[North Sydney Boys High School]].Chisholm, ''Who's Who in Australia 1947'', p. 780{{cite news|last=Llewelyn|first=Ken|title=Air ace decorated for daring feats|work=[[The Canberra Times]]|location=Canberra|date=9 September 2013|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/comment/obituaries/air-ace-decorated-for-daring-feats-20130908-2tdu9.html#ixzz2eowaQ2RY|accessdate=15 September 2013}} He recalled having always been interested in a military career, applying unsuccessfully to enter the [[Royal Australian Navy]] when he was twelve, and the [[Royal Military College, Duntroon]], after he left school and started working with the [[Perpetual Limited|Perpetual Trustee Company]].Steege; Llewellyn, "Oral history recording", Cassette 1/Side A On 21 July 1937, he joined the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF), undergoing flight instruction at [[No. 1 Flying Training School RAAF|No. 1 Flying Training School]] in [[RAAF Williams#RAAF Williams Point Cook Base|Point Cook]], Victoria.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/people_8291.asp|title= Air Commodore Gordon Henry Steege|publisher= [[Australian War Memorial]]|accessdate= 5 September 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/Veteran.aspx?serviceId=R&veteranId=1081196 |title=Steege, Gordon Henry|work=World War 2 Nominal Roll|accessdate= 5 September 2013}} He graduated with a distinguished pass on 23 June 1938, and was commissioned a [[pilot officer]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article35591080 |title=RAAF graduates receive badges|newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=24 June 1938 |accessdate=5 September 2013 |page=14 |publisher=[[National Library of Australia]]}} His first posting was to [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|No. 3 (Army Cooperation) Squadron]] at [[RAAF Base Richmond|RAAF Station Richmond]], New South Wales, flying [[Hawker Hart#Demon|Hawker Demon]] biplane fighters.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', pp. 46, 123 Steege and the squadron participated in several exercises with the [[Australian Army]], undertaking reconnaissance, spotting for artillery, and practising ground-attack missions.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', p. 214 He was promoted to [[flying officer]] in December 1938. ==World War II== Following the outbreak of World War II in September 1939, Steege was appointed [[adjutant]] of the newly formed [[No. 11 Squadron RAAF|No. 11 Squadron]], which initially operated two [[Short Brothers|Short Type C]] flying boats requisitioned from [[Qantas Empire Airways]]. Half of the squadron's personnel were Qantas employees.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', p. 61 On 25 September, No. 11 Squadron became the RAAF's first unit to be based in Papua New Guinea, when the flying boats, accompanied by Steege in a [[De Havilland Dragon Rapide]], flew to [[Port Moresby]] to undertake maritime reconnaissance in the region.Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/26/chapters/03.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 66]Stephens, ''The RAAF in the Southwest Pacific Area'', pp. 18–19 ===Middle East=== [[File:SUK14909SteegeGladiator1940.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|Flight Lieutenant Steege (fifth from right) and fellow No. 3 Squadron pilots with a Gladiator biplane in Egypt, c. January 1941|alt=Half a dozen or so men looking at a map on the tail unit of a military biplane]] Steege returned to No. 3 Squadron in May 1940, was promoted to [[flight lieutenant]] the following month, and shipped out to the [[Mediterranean and Middle East theatre of World War II|Middle East]] with his unit on 15 July.Garrisson, ''Australian Fighter Aces'', p. 160{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_11023second_world_war.asp |title=3 Squadron RAAF|publisher=Australian War Memorial|accessdate=28 November 2010}} Piloting a [[Gloster Gladiator]] biplane, he achieved his first aerial victory in the [[North African campaign]] when he shot down an Italian [[Fiat CR.42]] on 10 December 1940; he also claimed a "probable" in the same action.Thomas, ''Gloster Gladiator Aces'', p. 44 Three days later he shared in three more "kills": two CR.42s and a [[Savoia-Marchetti SM.79]]. After No. 3 Squadron converted to [[Hawker Hurricane]]s, Steege shot down three [[Junkers Ju 87]]s in a single sortie near [[Mersa Matruh]] on 18 February 1941, to become his unit's second [[flying ace|ace]]. Following this exploit, and the destruction of a [[Messerschmitt Bf 110]] on 3 April, he was awarded the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]].Thomas, ''Hurricane Aces 1941–45'', p. 49 The recommendation noted his "unfailing courage", and the award was promulgated in the ''[[London Gazette]]'' on 11 April.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/AWM192/00203/002030768.pdf |title=Recommendation: Distinguished Flying Cross|publisher= Australian War Memorial|accessdate= 26 November 2010}}{{LondonGazette|issue= 35131 |startpage=2041|date=8 April 1941|accessdate=on 26 November 2010}} Raised to [[Acting (rank)|acting]] [[squadron leader]], Steege was given command of the newly arrived [[No. 450 Squadron RAAF|No. 450 Squadron]] at [[Rayak (Riyaq)|Rayak]], Lebanon, on 31 May 1941.Herington, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/28/chapters/03.pdf ''Air War Against Germany and Italy'', p. 95] The assignment was a challenging one, as the operational requirements of existing forces, and the RAAF Air Board's insistence on staffing [[Article XV squadrons]] such as No. 450 with Australian [[British Commonwealth Air Training Plan|Empire Air Training Scheme]] aircrew rather than Permanent Air Force members, meant that the unit was short of experienced pilots.Herington, ''Air War Against Germany and Italy'', pp. 96–99 Steege was [[mentioned in despatches]] on 24 September 1941 for his leadership of the squadron.{{LondonGazette|issue=35284|supp=yes|startpage=5569|endpage=5573|date=24 September 1941|accessdate=on 26 November 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?iid=81198#folio=20|title=He lived his life to the full|work=[[Air Force (newspaper)|Air Force]]|last=Llewelyn|first=Ken|date=12 September 2013|page=20|accessdate=9 September 2013}} By December, it was at nominal strength and equipped with [[Curtiss P-40 variants|P-40 Kittyhawks]]; it commenced combat operations out of [[RAF Gambut|Gambut]] and [[Gamal Abdul El Nasser Air Base|El Adem]], Libya, and began registering victories in February 1942.Herington, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/28/chapters/09.pdf ''Air War Against Germany and Italy'', p. 218] Steege himself scored a confirmed victory over a [[Messerschmitt Bf 109]] on 28 March.Newton, ''Australian Air Aces'', p. 110 His final tally in the Middle Eastern theatre was eight enemy aircraft destroyed, two probables and five damaged.Thomas, ''Hurricane Aces 1941–45'', p. 88 He returned to Australia a temporary [[Wing Commander (rank)|wing commander]] in December 1942. ===South West Pacific=== [[File:Kittyhawk on Momote.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|P-40 Kittyhawks at Los Negros, 1944|alt=Single-engined military monoplane parked on a landing ground with palm trees in the background]] Steege undertook a fighter sector course in January 1943, and was given command of No. 8 Fighter Sector Headquarters in [[Brisbane]]. As a result, he later contended, of his petitioning [[Eastern Area Command (RAAF)|Eastern Area Command]] for reassignment to combat duties and complaining to Group Officer [[Clare Stevenson]] that there were too many [[Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force|WAAAFs]] in the sector for an unmarried man to supervise, he was posted to command [[No. 114 Mobile Control and Reporting Unit RAAF|No. 14 Mobile Fighter Sector Headquarters]] at [[Camden, New South Wales|Camden]], New South Wales, on 23 May.Steege; Llewellyn, "Oral history recording", Cassette 3/Side ARAAF Historical Section, ''Radar Units'', pp. 131–137 The following month, the unit deployed to [[Goodenough Island]] in [[New Guinea campaign|New Guinea]] as part of [[No. 71 Wing RAAF|No. 71 (Fighter) Wing]], becoming operational on 27 June. In August it moved to [[Kiriwina]], under the aegis of [[No. 73 Wing RAAF|No. 73 (Fighter) Wing]]. Steege relinquished command on 1 October to take charge of No. 73 Wing. The wing's combat units consisted of two P-40 Kittyhawk squadrons and a [[Supermarine Spitfire]] squadron.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/05.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 69] As part of the build-up to the [[Battle of Arawe]] in December, the Kittyhawks launched a series of assaults on [[Gasmata]]; three days before the Allied landings, Steege personally led a force of thirty-four aircraft in a bombing and strafing attack on the town's landing strip.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/08.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 126] In January 1944, the wing took part in the two largest raids mounted by the RAAF to that time, each involving over seventy aircraft attacking enemy camps and depots at Lindenhafen, [[New Britain]].Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/08.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 130–131] Steege was promoted acting [[group captain]] the following month; the rank was made temporary in July. As part of the RAAF's contribution to the [[Admiralty Islands campaign]], Steege led No. 73 Wing on garrison duty at [[Los Negros]], commencing in March 1944. The wing's combat squadrons—[[No. 76 Squadron RAAF|Nos. 76]], [[No. 77 Squadron RAAF|77]] and [[No. 79 Squadron RAAF|79]]—were supported by No. 49 Operational Base Unit, No. 114 Mobile Fighter Sector (formerly No. 14 Mobile Fighter Sector), No. 27 Air Stores Park and No. 26 Medical Clearing Station, among other ancillaries.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/11.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 170–177] The fighters' main duty was providing cover for Allied shipping; they also carried out bomber escort, ground attack and anti-shipping missions. In mid-April, the wing escorted the largest Allied convoy in the [[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific]] to that date, 80 ships carrying 30,000 personnel, from [[Finschhafen]] to [[Aitape]].Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/13.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 209] On 11 April, Steege was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]] for his "outstanding leadership in aerial combat in New Guinea".{{LondonGazette|issue=36463|supp=yes|startpage=1674|date=11 April 1944|accessdate=on 26 November 2010}} Completing their garrison work in the Admiralties that June, No. 73 Wing's Kittyhawk units were transferred to [[No. 81 Wing RAAF|No. 81 (Fighter) Wing]] on [[Noemfoor]] under Steege's command. In September 1944, No. 81 Wing became part of No. 10 Operational Group, which was renamed the [[Australian First Tactical Air Force]] the following month.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/15.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 249]Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/17.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 299] During October and November, No. 81 Wing undertook offensive sweeps and ground attacks against targets in [[West Papua (region)|West Papua]], and dive bombed Japanese airfields on [[Halmahera]].Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/18.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 304, 307–308, 312] Steege handed over command of the wing to Group Captain [[Wilfred Arthur|Wilf Arthur]] in December 1944.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/23.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 388] In January 1945, Steege became senior air staff officer (SASO) at Eastern Area Command in Sydney. He was posted to RAAF Headquarters, [[Melbourne]], in May. From June to December, he attended the [[National War College|Army and Navy Staff College]] in Washington, D.C. ==Korean War and after== [[File:JK0147SteegeMcCauleyKorea1951.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|Wing Commander Steege (centre) with Air Vice Marshal [[John McCauley (RAAF officer)|John McCauley]] (left) and Group Captain A.G. Carr (right) in South Korea, November 1951|alt=Three-quarter informal portrait of three men in military uniforms in front of the left wing of a twin-engined military monoplane]] Steege married Joan Tait on 5 January 1946; they had a son and a daughter. He was appointed RAAF Director of Operations in February. In December 1946, he resigned from the RAAF, joining the New Guinea Administration as a patrol officer the next month. He rejoined the Air Force as a wing commander on the outbreak of the [[Korean War]] in June 1950. The following month, he accompanied Major General [[William Bridgeford]]'s [[Malayan Emergency|mission to Malaya]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article44928355 |title=Military mission to Malaya |newspaper=The Advertiser |location=Adelaide |date=22 July 1950 |accessdate=5 September 2013 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Steege assumed command of [[RAAF Station Schofields]], New South Wales, in September 1950, and commenced a jet training course at [[RAAF Base Williamtown|RAAF Station Williamtown]] early the next year. On 16 August 1951, he was posted to [[Kimpo]], South Korea, as commander of No. 77 Squadron, shortly after its conversion from [[North American P-51 Mustang|P-51 Mustang]] piston-engined fighters to [[Gloster Meteor]] jets. One of his first actions, following discussions with the US [[Fifth Air Force]], was to take the Australian unit out of its then-current air-to-air combat role, and curtail its operations in "[[MiG Alley]]". Two encounters between No. 77 Squadron and Chinese [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15|MiG-15]]s had convinced Steege that the straight-winged Meteors were outclassed as fighters by the swept-wing MiGs. His decision caused controversy as some [[United Nations|UN]] commanders believed that proper training and tactics would have allowed the Meteor to remain competitive as a fighter, while for the Australian pilots the change of role amounted to a loss of prestige.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 236–237O'Neill, ''Combat Operations'', p. 358 However, Steege was backed up by the [[Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Chief of the Air Staff]], Air Marshal [[George Jones (RAAF officer)|George Jones]], and the squadron was relegated mainly to escort duty and local air defence. Morale suffered and it was not until after Steege's departure on 26 December that a suitable offensive role was again found for the Meteors, namely ground attack.Wilson, ''The Brotherhood of Airmen'', pp. 181–182 After returning to Australia, Steege was appointed chief instructor at the School of Land/Air Warfare, Williamtown, in February 1952. He was attached to the [[Department of Air (Australia)|Department of Air]] in [[Canberra]] for two years beginning in August 1953, holding secretarial posts on the Chiefs of Staff Committee, Joint Planning Committee, and Defence Committee.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article103123881 |title=Gp Capt Steege appointed to SEATO planners |newspaper=The Canberra Times |location=Canberra |date=15 October 1958 |accessdate=5 September 2013 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} After serving on the staff of [[Air Force Training Group RAAF|Headquarters Training Command]] from August 1955 to May 1957, he took command of [[Fairbairn, Canberra|RAAF Base Canberra]], Australian Capital Territory. At this time [[No. 86 Wing RAAF|No. 86 Wing]], operating [[Douglas C-47 Skytrain|Douglas Dakotas]] and [[Convair CV-240 family|Convair 440 Metropolitain]]s, was located at Canberra, in part to satisfy the Federal government's [[Very Important Person|VIP]] transport needs.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 416, 426Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', pp. 97–98 Steege was promoted to acting group captain in May 1958 ([[Military rank#Types of rank|substantive]] two months later), before becoming a senior planner at the [[Southeast Asia Treaty Organization|SEATO]] Military Planning Office, Bangkok, in December 1958. He returned to the Department of Air in December 1961, where he rose to Director of Plans. Promoted to [[air commodore]], he was appointed Officer Commanding (OC) [[RAAF Base Amberley]], Queensland, in November 1964. Amberley was home to the RAAF's bomber headquarters, [[No. 82 Wing RAAF|No. 82 Wing]], which operated [[English Electric Canberra]] jets.{{cite journal|author= Air Power Development Centre |date=September 2008 | title= Superbase #1: RAAF Amberley Past to Future | journal= Pathfinder | issue=97 | publisher= Royal Australian Air Force| url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/admin/productfiles/publication/materials/346/pf97_sept08.pdf}}{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/aircraft/series2/A84.htm |title=Canberra|publisher= [[RAAF Museum]]|accessdate=5 September 2013}} In May 1967, Steege became OC [[RMAF Butterworth|RAAF Base Butterworth]], Malaysia. The RAAF maintained two squadrons of fighters at Butterworth: [[No. 75 Squadron RAAF|No. 75 Squadron]] flying [[Dassault Mirage III|Dassault Mirages]], and also No. 77 Squadron flying [[CAC Sabre]]s until 1969, and the Mirage-equipped No. 3 Squadron after that.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article107046835 |title=Review team may decide RAAF units to be switched in re-shuffle |newspaper=The Canberra Times |location=Canberra|date=15 April 1968 |accessdate=5 September 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/aircraft/series3/A3.htm |title=Dassault Mirage III|publisher= RAAF Museum|accessdate=5 September 2013}} Returning to Australia, Steege served as SASO with Headquarters Operational Command (now [[RAAF Air Command|Air Command]]) at [[RAAF Base Glenbrook]], New South Wales, from May 1970 until retiring from the Air Force on 31 October 1972. ==Later life== After leaving the RAAF, Steege served as a consultant to several aerospace defence firms. In 2004, he married Jennifer Fisher, his partner since 1987. He maintained his connection with No. 450 Squadron in his later years. As a guest at the 1994 RAAF History Conference in Canberra he spoke at length on the difficulties of establishing the unit in the Middle East in 1941.Mordike, ''The RAAF in Europe and North Africa'', pp. 14–16, 61 He became patron of the squadron association in April 2008.{{cite journal|url=http://450squadronraaf.smugmug.com/gallery/5143404_SvnF4#!i=1161599204&k=vtv4tSV&lb=1&s=A|title=First commanding officer – now 450's patron|work=The Harasser|date=November 2009|page=1|accessdate=5 September 2013}} In 2010, he joined three fellow members of No. 3 Squadron who shipped out to the Middle East on 15 July 1940 for the 70th anniversary commemoration of the event at RAAF Base Richmond.{{cite web|url=http://3squadron.org.au/subpages/70thMarchOut.htm |title=70th Anniversary of 3 Squadron "Marching Out" to War|publisher= 3 Squadron RAAF Association|accessdate= 28 November 2010}} Steege made his home in [[Palm Beach, New South Wales|Palm Beach]], New South Wales, and died on 1 September 2013, aged 95.{{cite news|url=http://tributes.smh.com.au/obituaries/smh-au/obituary.aspx?n=gordon-steege&pid=166778795#fbLoggedOut|title=Tributes and celebrations: Gordon Steege|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=4 September 2013|accessdate=24 November 2014}} He was survived by his second wife, son and stepdaughter. ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== *{{cite book|last=Chisholm| first=Alec H.
